thread.title: Five reasons this is Australia’s new favourite show
thread.title_full: Five reasons this is Australia’s new favourite show

title: Five reasons this is Australia’s new favourite show
text:
Why Channel 7’s 800 Words has beaten the odds to become one of 2015’s biggest ratings successes Colin Vickery National TV Writer News Corp Australia Network Why Channel 7’s 800 Words has beaten the odds to become one of 2015’s biggest ratings successes Colin Vickery National TV Writer News Corp Australia Network 800 Words: sneak peek 1:20 
When his wife dies suddenly, George (Erik Thomson) makes a rash decision to move his two teenaged kids away from the big smoke of Sydney to the picturesque town of Weld in New Zealand. Coming soon to Seven. June 19th 2015 4 months ago /video/video.news.com.au/Entertainment/ 
WHY has 800 Words succeeded where so many other Australian shows have failed? That is the question many people are asking after the runaway success of Channel 7’s new drama. 
The show is averaging a whopping 1.4 million-plus across the five capital cities once catch-up viewing is added. It is consistently Tuesday night’s number one program and, even more remarkably, usually builds its audience on lead-in show The X Factor. 
800 Words has received generally favourable reviews and there is no denying the quality of the writing as well as the performances from Erik Thomson as George Turner as well as Melinda Vidler as daughter Shay and Benson Jack Anthony as son Arlo. Cast from Channel Seven (7) TV show 'Packed To The Rafters'. Rick Donald and Erik Thomson for 800 Words Packed to the Rafters final episode, Rebecca Gibney, Erik Thomson, 2013 Anne Tenney and John Howard star in the Channel 7 series, Always Greener. Actor Sigrid Thornton with William McInnes in scene from TV program "SeaChange". 1 of n 
But there is more to it than that. Here are my five reasons that 800 Words has struck such a chord with Aussie audiences. 
1. The Packed to the Rafters Halo Effect 
Packed to the Rafters is the biggest Aussie TV drama of the last decade and it was still rating strongly when Channel 7 ceased production in 2013 after six seasons. The big question was whether Erik Thomson and Rebecca Gibney could have the same level of success separately as they had teamed as Dave and Julie Rafter. The answer is a resounding ‘yes’. Gibney’s Winter rated strongly earlier this year, particularly once catch-up figures were added in, grabbing well over 1 million viewers across the five capital cities. Now Thomson’s 800 Words has done even better. Former Packed to the Rafters star Jessica Marais’ Love Child is a smash for Nine too. Rafters fans have flocked to all three new shows. Other Stories
